newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper futures end down on LME losses.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper futures end down on LME losses.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down in active trading on Thursday due to overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
The most active July 1997 contract ended at 23,740 yuan ($2,861) per tonne, losing 230 yuan. It opened at 23,750 yuan, hitting an intraday high of 23,790 and a low of 23,710 yuan.
April fell 90 to 23,390, May 140 to 23,480, June 200 to 23,660 and August 200 to 23,750 yuan per tonne.
Combined volume rose sharply to 52,990 tonnes from 24,570.
Copper opened lower on LME losses and moved at those levels for most of the session, traders said.
"Copper opened sharply down but did not fall further due to active buying at low levels," one trader said.
"Many investors believe copper will not drop sharply in the first half of this year," he said.
"A lot of Thursday's buying was short-covering orders because holders of those positions don't think there will be any further price falls," a second trader said.
Traders said many investors were eager to leave the metal market for the bullish stock market.
Analysts said they did not expect copper to fall further in the next few days.
Aluminium ended down. April fell 100 yuan to 16,150 yuan ($1,946) per tonne and May 90 to 16,430 yuan.
Combined volume fell to 410 tonnes from 2,300 yuan per tonne.
